Haus:
===Alternative forms===
* {{alter|de|Hauß||obsolete}}

===Etymology===
From {{inh|de|gmh|hūs}}, from {{inh|de|goh|hūs}}, from {{inh|de|gem-pro|*hūsą}}. Cognate with {{cog|got|*𐌷𐌿𐍃}}, {{cog|ofs|hūs}}, {{cog|nds|[[Hus]], [[Huus]]}}, {{cog|nl|huis}}, {{cog|is|hús}}, {{cog|fo|hús}}, {{cog|da|hus}}, {{cog|no|hus}}, {{cog|sv|hus}}, {{cog|en|house}}.

===Pronunciation===
* {{IPA|/haʊ̯s/|[haʊ̯s]|lang=de}}
* {{audio|De-Haus.ogg|audio|lang=de}}
* {{rhymes|aʊ̯s|lang=de}}

===Noun===
{{de-noun|n|Hauses|Häuser|Häuschen|dim2=Häuslein|dim3=Häusle|dim4=Häusel|dim5=Häus'l|dim6=Häusl}}

# [[house]]
#: {{ux|de|In dem '''Haus''' haben wir mal gewohnt.|t=We used to live in that '''house'''.|inline=1}}
#: {{ux|de|Mein Großvater starb in dem '''Haus''', wo ich geboren wurde.|t=My grandfather died in the '''house''' where I was born.|inline=1}}
# [[theatre]]

====Declension====
{{de-decl-noun-n|es|pl=Häuser}}

ab:
===Pronunciation===
* {{a|Germany}} {{IPA|/ap/|/ɑp/|lang=de}}
* {{a|Switzerland, Austro-Bavarian}} {{IPA|/ɑb̥/|lang=de}}
* {{rhymes|ap|lang=de}}

===Etymology 1===
From {{der|de|goh|ab}}, from {{der|de|gem-pro|*ab}}.

====Preposition====
{{head|de|preposition}}

# Beginning at that time or location; [[from]].
#: '''Ab''' heute verfügbar.
#:: ''Available '''from''' today.''

=====Derived terms=====
* {{l|de|ab und zu}}

===Etymology 2===
From adverbial use of the preposition in verbs such as [[abschlagen]], [[abgehen]] etc.

====Adjective====
{{head|de|adjective}}

# {{lb|de|colloquial|predicative}} [[off]]; not attached to anything anymore
#: Der Arm ist '''ab'''.
#:: ''The arm is (hewn) '''off'''.''
# {{lb|de|nonstandard|attributive}} [[off]]; not attached to anything anymore
#: Der '''abbe''' Arm ist verschwunden.
#:: ''The (hewn) '''off''' arm has disappeared.''

=====Usage notes=====
* The {{l|en|predicative}} use is common in colloquial German throughout the country.
* The {{l|en|attributive}} forms are mostly used in Western and Northern Germany and are considerably less common than the predicative use. They used to be used mostly {{l|en|jocular|jocularly}}, but become gradually more frequent since they are much shorter than the appropriate full verb forms such as {{m|de|abgetrennt||disconnected, severed}}.
* The inflected attributive forms retain the devoiced consonant. Hence, sometimes they are spelled with ''p'', rather than ''b'': ''Appes Bein''.

===Related terms===
* {{l|de|abseits}}
dies:
===Pronunciation===
* {{IPA|[ˈdiːs]|lang=de}}
* {{audio|De-dies.ogg|Audio|lang=de}}
* {{rhymes|iːs|lang=de}}

===Pronoun===
{{de-pronoun}}

# {{alternative form of|dieses|lang=de}}

====Usage notes====
In the nominative and accusative neuter, the forms ''dieses'' and ''dies'' are in general interchangeable, but there is a tendency to prefer one or the other in the following situations:
* In adjectival usage, ''dieses'' is generally preferred to ''dies''. So ''dieses Haus'' ("this house") is more common than the also correct and synonymic ''dies Haus''.
* In substantival usage, ''dieses'' is used to refer to a previously used neuter noun:
:: ''Unser Unternehmen sollte das Gebäude verkaufen. Wir können '''dieses''' nicht mehr gebrauchen.''
::: Our company should sell the building. We cannot make use of it anymore.
* ''Dies'' is used to refer to a preceding context or phrase:
:: ''Unser Unternehmen sollte das Gebäude verkaufen. '''Dies''' würde uns viel Geld einbringen.''
::: Our company should sell the building. This would earn us a lot of money.
: ''Dies'' is also used to refer to something the speaker perceives with the senses ([[deixis]]):
:: ''Sieh dir '''dies''' mal an!'' – Have a look at this! (e.g. a newspaper article)
* The above habits are mainly true of formal speech and writing. Colloquially, the shorter ''dies'' is often preferred, but the pronouns {{m|de|das}} and {{m|de|es}} are even more common.

===Further reading===
* {{R:Duden}}
o:
===Interjection===
{{head|de|interjection}}

# [[O]]
#* '''1843''', Gallus Schwab, ''Gebetbuch für katholische Christen'', Bamberg, p.45:
#*: Sei gegrüßet, '''o''' Du mein Jesu! Mit tieftster Demuth bete ich Dich an und verehre Dich!
